comments.body: AMAZING. 'Bout the best idea i've heard so far! Hope this is implemented into the game! ;)

Big fan of this one. This biome could help out with minecrafts lighting issues by not just adding new lighting, but maybe even Adding an item that can prevent mob spawning without lighting up the area. 

I was inspired by you feedback post so much that i ended up making my own similar post. I think were both on to something great here! keep up the good work!

This is a really neat idea!! I'm a huge fan of the deep sea and think it would be a really cool thing to play around with. Following the theme of this biome, we could add waves to the ocean in general- and with that, maybe some things like shells or scutes or even ingots, could wash up. I think it would also be cool if the new villagers were actually a new merfolk mob, and they traded with pearls that you could find in giant clams that sort of function like shulker mobs. To make things easier, you could have these clams in overworld oceans and have the Deep Clams give rare black pearls, or just place them in the deep. This post made me super inspired and now I'm disappointed that they didn't do this in the Ocean Update.

Yes on fog. But I'd like for it to be a slider option in the menu of the game that players can intensify to the point where you can't see anything but white and the glow of light objects/creeking eyes, or a super subtle thin fog layer for atmosphere and nothing else, or just get rid of it entirely. The player can choose the intensity.

I'd also like either fireflies that glow the same color of the creeking eyes and exist all day long to throw off the players and have them be disoriented almost when the creeking comes out. The other option is you could add really cool like soul flames almost floating around and guiding players to either a new structure or their impending death like a lava pit or ravine, that would also be cool.

Cobwebs and random holes in the ground should generate in the biome.

Cause if Mojang is trying to make this spooky they need to go all out with the Environmental Storytelling and scattered journals from that era before, after, and during the collapse of the Ancient Builder Society. I had an idea where it would be caused by the Wither. Where wherever you spawn the wither he'll kill everything around him in a large area, turning the grass grey, with a new tainted soil block. The trees lose the leaves and the bark turns black. This is also a way to add the wither flower into the over world. There would be a variant zombie in the area that's also grey and dusty. And if the wither attacks a village it makes them all dusty too, leaving charred ruins.

This biome also has a rare chance to spawn on it's own in the over world. when it spawns on it's own there would also be new cave generations. Such as circular pits that drop down, like craters, as well as craters. Perhaps underground in the caves Netherack would spawn occasionally like granite or andesite. There would be a higher chance to find a abandoned, portal, and village ruins with dusty village zombies would spawn. 

I don't know if this is possible.... but to have it be cloudier above the biome itself. perhaps having that be a way to see it from a distance.  

I think that it would create a nice contrast against temperate areas that are very green. And it would almost be like a bit of lore as well (adding to the dramatic power of the wither).

 

I'm sorry I feel like I'm piggybacking. Generally I think that a wasteland biome would create some really cool contrast with the biomes around it. And I love the mushrooms. love me some mushrooms and red sand.

I like the direction you're headed however, i feel that a Heat Exhaustion bar should be added and you must drink water bottles to keep the bar up as food for saturation. You would collect the water before adventuring into the biome and water bottles should be stackable.

Perhaps the mobs will be different, while still having the slider boss and flying pig. Maybe "ethereals" could be the replacement for villagers and piglins, relying on a reputation system to choose If they'd trade with you or not.

Maybe guards called "sepharims" could guard their homes, perhaps called kingdoms..

 

In addition, more biomes and mobs, as well as typical Minecraft quirkiness like a new fun way to get around would be fine. 

 

My only two suggestions: Make ethereals a thing and keep the slider and flying pigs.

But you can only get to the aether when you defeated the ender dragon.

And you can find a very rare new ore in the aether, that you can craft together with elytrias to wings.

It would be great to have it added.
Yes aether in minecraft is a good idea

yes in both bedrock and java edition would be great

I do like the idea of a purely underground dimension.  I am still unsure, though.

@Bilbo Baggins 

Fair enough, I just thought it would be less laggy than an expansion to the overworld's caves is all.

I am actually intrigued by the idea. I agree the world needs to be deeper, especially at the oceans. Would you consider having flooded tunnels in your dimension?

Love the idea! I would like to see it come to the real game. You have my vote!
Cubic chunks would allow the expansion of the caverns, without making the world lag more.

@The McExplorer, perhaps, perhaps...deep abyssal oceans could be something you could find here going up all the way to the ceiling of that dimension to give the impression it is part of the overworld ocean, lots of ghastly creatures could appear there too! Also what if these deep ocean/flooded caves were directly accessible by ocean monuments to encourage finding them and be an alternative award to sponges and gold.

This reminds me of a quote from Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings, when he's describing the "uttermost foundations of stone" - "Far, far below the deepest delvings of the Dwarves, the world is gnawed by nameless things. Even Sauron knows them not. They are older than he. Now I have walked there, but I will bring no report to darken the light of day."

Very good ideas! I think each one could be their own post, because it seems to me they could work even if a deeper underground dimension was not implemented.

I think there should be a different way to get there than going down a ladder for several reasons:

  • Steve has to rely on someone else long ago/world generation to get there, which means he can't make the passages wider, or change them in hardly any way.
  • Older worlds upgrading will have to explore new chunks to be able to get down.
  • Since this place would be a different dimension, there would need to be a loading screen while you transition from one part of the ladder to the other. This would make going up difficult because you have to make sure you keep holding "forward" when the loading screen ends. (unless they could figure out a way to switch dimensions without loading screens, which would mean having chunks from both dimensions loaded at the same time...)

An alternative is this:

The player crafts a diamond chisel (stick + diamond). They use a chisel on a bedrock block, and it becomes a partially damaged bedrock block, and the chisel is destroyed. They repeat this 63 more times, each time, the bedrock getting more damaged, until it becomes cracked bedrock. Cracked bedrock may then be mined with a diamond pickaxe, and is either destroyed, or drops a cracked bedrock block which someone can come up with a use for.

When the last bedrock block has been destroyed, the player can jump out of the world, and their feet will land on y=-2, so they are standing entirely beneath the bedrock. At this point, they will be blind to everything because of a fog, so a floor doesn't even need to created in the overworld, just a collision plane. Upon contact with this plane, they are sent to the underground dimension (presumably with a loading screen), and they find themselves with their head between y=254 and y=255 (same x and z), and their feet on y=253. The entire top layer of this dimension is the entire bottom layer of the overworld, so they can faintly see (because of the fog) the bedrock they broke just above their head.

The fog would hover around all bedrock layers in the overworld, underground, and nether.

So the player doesn't start suffocating when they enter the underground, the second-to-top layer of the undergound would be a transparent block, maybe "bedrock gas", "bedrock glass", or something that breathes like a liquid, so they will start suffocating if they stand there too long.

Once there, you just have to dig down.

To get back up, you just have to reach where your feet are standing on y=255, and you will be teleported to the overworld standing on y=-1 at the corresponding x and z. You won't get teleported back down by standing there, so you would have to jump out of the hole, and back in if you wanted to go back down, similar to how you have to exit and enter a nether portal to go back through.

 

@Noobly20932 chunks are already cubic, that is, each "chunk" is 16 16x16x16 sections grouped together. The real challenge would be organizing them into cubic region files and implementing 3-dimensional world generation. That would be really cool, though - to see a ravine so deep the bottom doesn't even render because it's too far away.

@ Avari six that is an alternative, perhaps your way could be considered in lore the way the mining huts appeared? Either way it’s a good idea and I like the thought of another tool in Minecraft, perhaps this chisel could be used for carvings as well?

@PolarMammoth After thinking about it, a ladder would still work with the suggestion I gave, so you wouldn't have to change any of the lore after all! I guess my suggestion was additive, not alternative :). It maybe would be a nice touch if many of the miner's huts were unfinished holes (you find damaged bedrock where the hole would be), and a smaller amount are complete with a ladder.

As far as alternative uses of the chisel, here are a few I found from doing a search:

  • https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360011280111-More-Chiseled-Block-Versions-Chisel
  • https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360042929491-The-Chisel-Detail-Pick-A-solution-to-the-8th-block-problem-
  • https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360036800292-Lime-stone-

None mention making sculptures, so that could be a new post of its own! That makes me think of how paintings work, based on the size of the material you chisel, a corresponding statue is made...

@avari six

I’ll take a look see at those suggestions too.

Unaware of this thread, I recently attempted to suggest a simpler version of extending the underground, but Ms. Barlow removed it and I have no access to the original text. Needless to say, I am a fan of this idea. :-) Minecraft would be a deeper, richer experience if it allowed us to plunge past the bedrock in certain opened areas that let us slip through, finding another world below.

I'm not so crazy about the idea of making this a "dimension." It would be so much better to have it progress linear from the point of bedrock, and at the bottom of this stratum, it's all deep magma (the source of the Nether's ceiling streams). I was not aware this was a technical hurdle to overcome (memory issue?), but it sure would be fascinating to have new creatures, ores, and challenges to contend with down there.

@Marc Adrian

I believe everyone’s comments are considered on a post that’s reached the amount of votes qualifying for review, so I do not think if my post were included into the game in some sort of cave update it would be exact, more likely it would turn out a dimension that contains a hybrid of everybody’s ideas in this thread. So even though you do not have access to your original post, your ideas (Which are interesting btw) would most likely be considered just as much as mine.

Sounds overcomplicated. Just make it so this is an area that removes bedrock and instead makes the world continue on deeper. Everything else is nice but the ores could have more usage. Radium along with that could be crafted into a block that damages you when you are around it while also giving off an extreme Redstone signal. Along with tin, copper could be added to make bronze. With bronze, you could make new armor and tools. More ores could be added too.

I Don't think we need more dimensions especially just a cave dimension but we do need deeper worlds it is far to quick to dig down to diamond levels and not much of interest to find. Adding underground biomes, and structures which bring a sense of exploration and would give reason to actually go mining (since honestly you don't need to to beat the game at the moment.)

I like the spirit of this idea, but I think the real issue here is world generation. Build height is insane compared to sea level, and a natural way to create deeper caves (and oceans) would be to raise sea level a bit. But of course the best solution would be to render chunks in a 3D way rather than in a circle around the player, like with the cubic chunks mod mentioned above.

That said, if the easiest way to expand underground is with a new dimension I am all for it. I would just ask that the dimension be made to feel more like an extension of underground, rather than a new dimension. The more seamless it can fit with the overworld, the better.
Sounds great however I think it could work as a biome That spawns deep underground with cubic chunks
Maybe it could be a world option; Default, Superflat, Large Biomes, and then Deeper worlds. This option would generate the deeper underground without the need of adding a dimension probably?

@mariomcpokemon

Awesome idea! Or perhaps just "deeper worlds" as an option. Of course, the sky/cloud height should be raised, too, but that's another thread. :)

@Galiantis

The idea of entering the dimension via a ladder was suggested to actually make it seem as if you are just going deeper rather than to an actual dimension which would be a bit strange in my opinion. This way you’d have a whole dimension to generate huge caverns as high as cathedrals without needing cubic chunks and the feeling that the world is deeper past “the bedrock crust”
I feel like this would add some great additions to the 1.18 update.

I agree with this 100 percent, but I have an add-on idea. Maybe you have to find a certain place to get to this deep underground place (like, you have to dig under a mountain or shipwreck) in order to find it.

I have toyed around with world gen calculations to replicate the stone forest biome, and it is quite difficult to make something look natural using mathematical equations, however this is a naturally occurring phenomena in our world, and I was able to replicate something similar to what you see in this picture.
By messing around with tangents in x in the z coordinates, it made something very close in resemblance to the stone forest biome.

Note I am no world gen expert.

The thing is, I prefer the End as an empty wasteland. I don't view it as a place to explore, other than for end cities (and the obvious boss fight). I view it as an empty place, devoid of life. While Dungeons may have an interesting take on the End, it falls into line with the lore revolving around that dimension, along with the novel The End. If they did an End update, perhaps make different kinds of end cities, but I'd like the biomes to stay the same, along with just endermen, endermites, and shulkers.

I would more prefer a cave with ice veins, kind of like pre-generated stalactites and stalagmites, that when broken or melted turn into flowing water. Permanent water would just be a hassle for anyone who gets unlucky with where they decide to mine, so temporary water should make the cave more alive.

Here's my spin on it:

 

Tilting basalt spikes sticking out of the lava in nether

 

One spike

 

The inside of a spike (Some have 2-3 obsidian blocks inside, others don't)

 

Group of them (The real size of the groups would be slightly bigger, around 8-12 spikes more)

Big, tilting basalt spikes that generate in small groups sticking out of the lava in the nether would be really cool to stumble across. Not only would they serve as an obstacle when riding the strider, but they would look intimidating as well as being a kind of risky source of obsidian in the nether because inside some of the spikes you can find a small amount of obsidian. 

The spikes would have an outer layer of basalt, with magma blocks on the bottom and a small amount of obsidian inside each spike. They would also be quite rare.

 

The spikes wouldn't have to be made of basalt, I just like how they look when made of it.

While the idea of adding new planets and portals to Minecraft is intriguing, the suggestion needs some refinement. Starting with the moon and Mars is a good idea, and it would be great to see more accurate resources and portal materials added. However, the suggestion contains some factual errors regarding materials, resources, and crafting recipes that should be corrected.

i think the game cant support deep oceans at the moment especially with the depth of worlds in the game but with the new deep dart caves and the new cave generation they could be increasing that depth personally id love to see this added it'd atleast give the glow squid a reason to be there cause oceans are really that dark currently

Yeah I think the deep dark oceans would add a horror aspect to the game since minecraft doesn't really have many scary things in it since the scariest thing in minecraft is probably certain parts of the nether or the new warden mob coming next update. I think the deep dark oceans should have angler fish, goblin sharks, and some other scary underwater mobs. The way to get to the deep dark ocean should be that there is a darker/black spot in the ocean a hundred or so blocks away from land and you have a choice to go down there since if you were pulled down into the deep dark ocean that would most likely scar a little kid who wasn't planning on getting scared. I think once you get down to the deep dark there are little caves with air so you don't drown if you forgot a water breathing potion or something, but stay in pocket of air too long and something dark could come and get you. There would be chests full of valuable items in the deep dark ocean, mobs that drop special stuff, etc., but since there are rare/good rewards being down in the deep dark would be really challenging, nearly every mob that spawns there is hostile, there is little to no light, and your struggling for oxygen (unless you have a conduit or water breathing potion of course). Sorry if that was a bit long but I just had to put all my ideas out there, I have more ideas but then that would make this comment way too long.

@Hammysaur, a bit ambitious but your ideas are great! Having the deep dark oceans away from land would make it something exiting to venture too, and new players wouldn't accidentally stumble upon then early on in their worlds as well. Making it a struggle to stay down in the deep ocean with more hostile mobs would certianly make it more intimidating (possibly higher spawn of trident drowned?)! I'm also realizing that if you die deep down, your stuff will also spread out further along the top of the water. Could possibly also have some overhanging arches above the hole that could "catch" some items, making it more of a struggle to get all your items back.

This idea is so cool. I think that the deep oceans would likely be possible with the current depth, if you really squeezed it in there. OMG more trident drowned would be AMAZING, I would love that feature to get added.

This would be great. Having a "Continental Shelf" or even "Ocean Ravines" that went down to deep slate would be pretty neat. I think some deep sea mobs would be good to add, like halibut. To encourage folks to explore this deep something like giant clams with pearls inside would be fitting. Pearls could be used for brewing potions, white dye, and villager trading. Giant squid that are hostile could add some fear to the deep as well, but that may be pushing it in terms of content.

Three things:

1. I disagree that you should require a specific enchantment to kill the mobs.

2. The boss could be the Hovering Inferno or alternatively a new an improved way to summon the wither (instead of waiting for 3 2.5% chances to eventually occur from killing wither skeletons).

3. Consider the portal pertaining in some way to the Soul Sand Valley. Either you build it out of soul soil, or it can require being created inside a Soul Sand Valley. Perhaps a third option is that the Deep Nether has 4 biomes representing extreme versions of the preexisting Nether Biomes (Dark being only the one for the Soul Sand Valley).

Though, I do agree that this is another good way to obtain netherite.

I agree that this should be added, but it may not be as self explanatory as you think; give some characteristics on this biome, please.
I'd love seeing 100+ block tall, 5 block thick trees. This needs to happen

They need to be at least 3 x 3 blocks wide and must be fire resistant.

And add rare trees that are even wider like 5 x 5 or even 6 x 6

I'd love this! I think it also could spread awareness about how redwood trees are endangered! Would love to see trees 5-6x taller than the ancient pines, and would be astounded by a tree base with a circumference of around 6-7 blocks (or larger). Would love to see some great detail in these trees as well, and maybe the occasional fallen tree (like in pocket edition forests) or dead tree. Probably better to keep it as a pretty rare biome to insinuate the degree to which it is endangered, and making the trees take a long time to grow from saplings/pine cones. Redwoods would be the only deciduous-coniferous cross in the game as well. The same wood and leaf type could have three distinct shapes (as ancient pines & pines already do) to represent giant sequoias, dawn redwoods, and coast redwoods, representing three different extremely rare forests.
I believe they should use redwood in the Mega Taigas instead of Spruce. After all, in Bedrock they were called redwood forests. They can keep the giant spruce, but have redwood trees be the default.

Redwood trees and redwood biomes would be an amazing fit for Minecraft. The bark should have a reddish hue bur should be lighter and closer to pink when stripped. The trees should be massive, way taller than the taiga trees and the width should range from 2 blocks wide to maybe 5 or 6 blocks wide. the floors of this redwood biome should be covered in vegetation and there should be variety in the height as in real life redwood forests are very hilly. I think this biome should be rare but not impossible to find like the mangrove swamps. Adding these trees would also give great awareness to the real life forests since they are endangered.
